descriptiveNote.p: [Domhnall a' Bhrocair; Am Brocair]; foxhunter, Mill of Fasnacloich, Glencreran, Appin

biogHist.p: Donald MacColl, foxhunter, was born in Glen Creran, Appin, the illegitimate son of Rachel Cameron and, reputedly, John MacColl, shepherd. This John was the son of Duncan MacColl, Dunnchadh Dhomhnaill mac Iain Duibh, who had fought at Culloden under James Stewart of Fasnacloich. An enemy bullet went through his thigh, while another carried off his scabbard from the hilt; he narrowly escaped with his life.

Donald MacColl married Anne or Agnes Rankin (c. 1796–1880) from Corrychurrachan in the Parish of Kilmallie, daughter of Donald Rankin, crofter, and Mary MacColl, on 29 June 1823. He told Carmichael that there were nine children from the marriage: seven daughters, three of whom had died in Glasgow, and two sons, one of whom ‘took early to sea & is now on grund a chuain’, the other a ‘shep[herd] in Mull (An t Saobhai[dh])’ [CW120/68]. Census accounts, however, suggest only four girls and two boys; MacColl may possibly have been referring to the number of children brought up in his household, including granddaughters. In 1841 the family were living in Salachail towards the head of Glen Creran, but by 1851 they had moved down to Fasnacloich, where the couple were to stay until their deaths. By 1871 Donald had retired, while in the 1881 census he is recorded as ‘Pauper, was a Foxhunter’, living with his 48-year old daughter Mary and her daughter Mary Stevenson, aged 11.

A celebrated local character and one of the best sources for the oral tradition of his native district of Appin, ‘Am Brocair’ was interviewed by Alexander Carmichael during at least three long recording sessions in the autumn of 1883, on 29 August and the 27–28 September. Although it is not at all clear where these interviews begin and end, the lack of other names suggests that, with the exception of a single Fenian lay, all Appin tradition written into the first half of the notebook CW120 was taken down from Donald MacColl himself.

Even in Carmichael’s rushed notes, translated as they were jotted down, MacColl’s force of character comes through clearly: he had no hesitation in informing his interviewer that he knew he ‘was [from the] north from my Gaelic!’ [CW120/65] The repetition of certain rhymes, mainly connected with the local saint Curalan or Cyril, may be evidence of the ‘Senile Decay’ given as the cause of MacColl’s death some three years later, but is more likely to be due to Carmichael attempting to elicit further details of a subject which had obviously awakened his curiosity: maybe the saint would make a good subject for a newspaper column. The first interview between them appears to have ended with a walk up to the site of Cladh Churalain, the graveyard of St Cyril, on the slopes of Beinn Churalain, from where MacColl showed Carmichael landmarks in Benderloch opposite [CW120/97].

Donald MacColl had retired from his trade when Carmichael met him, and was full of anecdotes and experiences from a lifetime spent hunting foxes with his ‘doggies’: 53 years altogether, on average killing fifty of his quarry yearly, making a grand total of over 2,500 animals over his entire career [CW120/63]. ‘He had innumerable interesting and instructive stories about foxes and other wild animals, among which he had lived most of his long life of nearly one hundred years’ [Carmina Gadelica vol. ii, 381n.5]. Like many of his kind, he was fascinated by the shrewd and devious ways of foxes: for example, if the female is killed, the male takes on responsibility for their cubs: ‘There is no other fear tai[ghe] in Britain better’ [CW120/69]. ‘Many a time the foxes took a turn out of me. But many a time I took a turn out of them in return’ [CW120/69].

MacColl gave Carmichael some variant details about the history of his own kindred, supposedly derived from a bastard son of ‘Moraire Donullach’ who fled Skye for the Island of Coll after having committed a murder [CW120/70]. As a reward for hospitality shown to the Duke of Argyll, the MacColl dùthchas of Glasdrum in Glen Creran had been given to them as gràinnseach or a granary along with Corrabheinn for mutton. The feu duty for the farm was paid to the Stewarts of Appin, with the còir or charter being ‘car[ried] on per[son] or kept in [a] cos dar[aich] [oak hollow] or under a stone. The MacColls [were] strong[er] than the S[t]ew[art]s of Ap[pin]’ [CW120/164]. Other subjects touched upon included the sixteenth-century hero Domhnall nan Òrd of Invernahyle, the quarrels between the Stewarts of Appin and the Campbells, the Forty-Five, the clearances, the last of the Stewarts of Appin, local wedding and funeral customs, and buried treasures in the neighbourhood.

The subject which clearly appealed to Carmichael the most, however, was material concerning the local saint Curulan or Cyril: MacColl retailed for him various legends of his life, together with details of his church, graveyard, and healing well. Most intriguing of all is a series of references to ‘naoimh deilbh’ or images of Curulan and his fellow saint Moluag, once kept in the church but burnt by three ‘scamps’, apparently in the late eighteenth century [CW120/75]. These scamps were in fact the sons of local gentry, and their actions are probably to be ascribed to adolescent yahooism rather than reformation iconoclasm. All three were said to have suffered agonising deaths as a result [CW120/83, CW120/88, CW120/122].

Donald MacColl told Carmichael that he had seen Sir Walter Scott (1771–1832) several times when the novelist was visiting Fasnacloich [CW120/63, CW120/67, CW120/86, CW120/153]. He had met and spoken to Donnchadh Bàn nan Òran, Duncan Bàn Macintyre (1724–1812), in Glasdrum while the poet was travelling around the Highlands with his wife Mary Macintyre (c1750–1824), better known as Màiri Bhàn Òg, collecting subscriptions for the third edition of his songs, published in 1804 [CW120/176].

Although MacColl told Carmichael he had ‘no oran luai[dh] no oran bhuana’ [CW120/172], he did sing him at least one song, a version of Hi hiù ro bhò chan eil mi slàn, an air better known today in the Canadian Maritimes [CW120/168].

Carmichael may have visited Donald MacColl on another occasion, as is suggested by an anecdote ascribed to him in Carmina Gadelica, but not found in the field notebooks, concerning a discovery earlier in the century of ‘masses of wheatears’, apparently hibernating under a bank [CG ii, 251; also 345]. On the other hand, the ascription of a Sian Sionnaich or Charm against Foxes to Donald MacColl in Carmina [CG ii, 128–9] appears to have been done as a gesture of piety towards the foxhunter’s memory. The practical MacColl would have little use for Carmichael’s rather elaborately pious incantation, which seems to have been derived in reality from an Òr an t-Sionnaich given him by Mary Stewart or Màiri Bhreac, an old dairymaid in Malacleit, North Uist, on 19 March 1877 [CW108/4].
Donald was a widower at the time of his death in 1886 and the cause was recorded as senile decay, and his daughter Mary MacColl signed the certificate.
